Award.AwardTitle: FRG Collaborative Research: Generalized Geometry, String Theory and Deformations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a multi-institutional (Harvard, Brandeis and Texas A&M), interdisciplinary (mathematics and physics) effort to study the mathematical theory of generalized geometries and its applications to string theory. Generalized geometries form a class of almost complex manifolds with reduced structure groups, which have become of central importance to the study of realistic string theory models. These are natural generalizations of Calabi-Yau manifolds and are of mathematical interest in their own right. In one class important for string theory, the canonical structure one seeks on a generalized Calabi-Yau manifold is governed by a fully nonlinear complex Monge Ampere type system that couples a balanced Hermitian metric to an anti self-dual connection of a vector bundle. When the manifold is Kahler Calabi-Yau and the vector bundle is the tangent bundle, this system reduces to the Calabi conjecture for Ricci-flat metrics. Generalized geometries arise as the internal component of spacetime of string theory models that are much closer to our real world than previous constructions. The mathematics that governs such a geometry is a natural extension of deep problems in geometric analysis, algebraic geometry, and deformation theory. The physics that is behind the new geometry provides inspiration and novel approaches to posing and solving the mathematical problems. Their solutions will in turn lead to greater understanding of fundamental problems in physics, making this a truly interdisciplinary collaboration.

The mathematical understanding of generalized geometries is still in its nascent stage. The purpose of this proposal is to develop this field further, into a full-fledged extension of Kahler Calabi-Yau geometries. We will focus on the following tightly interconnected problems: constructing new solutions to string theory in this class; characterizing deformations and specifically the moduli of these spaces; computing the dimension of the space's light fields; and an understanding of "generalized calibrations" - the analog of calibrated submanifolds of special holonomy manifolds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF FRG grant, covering the period 08/01/2012 - 03/31/2017, was a multi-institutional (Harvard, Brandeis and Texas A&M), interdisciplinary (mathematics and physics) effort to study the mathematical theory of generalized geometries and its applications to string theory. Research activities, as outlined in the original FRG research proposal of 2011, supported by the award have largely achieved their objectives. They include bringing together experts from both mathematics and physics to share their insights on the project, training a generation of young researchers from both subjects to carry out the research, and informing existing outreach and secondary education by research team members. These efforts were led by Shing-Tung Yau, the PI at Harvard University on this grant.

An over-arching goal of this project was to understand and elucidate an emerging class of new geometries, known as "Generalized Geometries", which arise naturally both in mathematics and physics over the last three decades. They are not only natural generalizations of the much better understood Calabi-Yau geometry, but they are singled out by "Nature" as a class of consistent geometric background in which Nature's fundamental hypothetical constituents - strings -propagate. Our goal was to understand and unlock, using the intricate consistency constraints imposed by Nature as well as the mathematical structures these new geometries enjoy, the "secrets" behind these highly nontrivial structures: how they can be constructed, why they exist, and in what way a physical theory can be consistently formulated as a realistic model on geometric spaces carrying these structures.

During the grant period, in addition to the stated research activities, including regular and extensive consultations, communications, and collaborations among the research team members from all three collaborating schools, the award at Harvard supported 2 graduate students and 3 postdoctoral fellows, and organized 3 separate FRG research workshops at Harvard University. These activities had produced a total 19 joint research papers among its team members that acknowledged the support of the FRG award at Harvard. The papers primarily aimed to study generalized geometries in a wide variety of different set-ups and viewpoints, in an effort to decipher the deep structures hidden in the various attributes (or invariants) of a generalized geometry. Their unlocking requires a range of techniques and insights from nonlinear partial different equations, group theory, differential geometry, as well as quantum field theory. The research team members involved in this project each brought to the effort their unique skills and expertise from their own background and training, in order to produce a synthesis of ideas that in turn led to solutions to problems in generalized geometries. The research papers were results of these joint efforts. Collectively, this research team has successfully achieved the intellectual merit proposed by the project. Results from this team and outside experts were reported in workshops and conferences. Among them are three workshops supported by this grant and held at Harvard on three separate occasions.

Further information about them can be found at the following links:

http://www.math.harvard.edu/conferences/frg12/index.html

http://www.math.harvard.edu/conferences/frg15/index.html

http://www.math.harvard.edu/conferences/frg16/index.html

As part of its broader impact, the Harvard PI has led a collaborative effort with team members from Brandeis to engage secondary school students in summer school research. Findings from this project were part of the basis for the some of the summer school courses and research projects. In addition to secondary education, this FRG award has supported the training of 2 graduate students and 3 postdoctoral fellows in this interdisciplinary field of research involving both mathematics and physics. All five young researchers are now considered "bilingual" experts in their respective areas of research. The graduate students were Jie Zhou and Jonathan Zhu, and the postdoctoral fellows were Illarion Melnikov, An Huang and Can Kozcaz. All five of them has successfully acquired the skills and mathematical maturity to continue and expand their inquiries into the challenging subject of generalized geometries. After their training at Harvard, each of these researchers has successfully joined other schools either as a junior research fellow or as a member on the research faculty in the U.S. or abroad. Their career success is indicative of the training they acquired during the project, which had helped made them highly competitive among a new generation of research mathematicians.
